timeline.bodyText: Tighten scope of url to be local to this try block, instead of class-scope. One you call onResult.accept(..) you shouldn't need to hang onto it any longer.
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

timeline.bodyText: For all places where it is used in this PR, Exception is too loose; try to catch something specific. That way, your recovery suggestion can be targeted. "Look at the call stack" isn't too great of a recovery suggestion. (This said, I myself have often found it difficult to come up with good recovery exception messages.)
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

replies.bodyText: I did this because I honestly couldn't figure out how AmazonS3Client#generatePresignedUrl() could ever fail. As long as the credentials are correctly setup in the first try-catch, I don't see a case where PresignedUrl generation would fail. I only try-caught it because it says it can throw AmazonClientException.
replies.author: raphkim

timeline.bodyText: Do we even need to spec this on the client side? Doesn't S3 have its own value that it will choose on the backend, if we don't provide one in outgoing request, at all?
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams
timeline.diffHunk:

         return storageService.getClient();
     }

+                options.getTargetIdentityId(),
+                options.getExpires() != 0 ? options.getExpires() : DEFAULT_EXPIRE_IN_SECONDS

replies.bodyText: It does, but that happens if null is passed as expiration Date object. I just think it's rather dirty to check if expires is zero and and pass a null object to the backend.
replies.author: raphkim

timeline.bodyText: It is not common practice to nest try-catch like this. See if you can unwrap the inner one, so that you are at most one try-catch deep in the method body at one time.
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

timeline.bodyText: I guess this one has to stay if you make a call to the mobile client, since it is part of the mobile client's method signature. (eyeroll)
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

timeline.bodyText: Since this class is meant to be particular to the details of S3, here, you could even name this like AWSS3GetPresignedUrlOperation or something.
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

timeline.bodyText: Maybe it can be named urlLifetimeInSeconds instead of expires, for greater clarity?
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

+package com.amplifyframework.storage.s3.request;
+
+import com.amplifyframework.storage.StorageAccessLevel;
+
+/**
+ * Parameters to provide to S3 that describe a request to retrieve
+ * pre-signed object URL.
+ */
+public final class AWSS3StorageGetUrlRequest {
+    private final String key;
+    private final StorageAccessLevel accessLevel;
+    private final String targetIdentityId;
+    private final int expires;
+
+    /**
+     * Constructs a new AWSS3StorageGetUrlRequest.
+     * @param key key for item to obtain URL for
+     * @param accessLevel Storage access level
+     * @param targetIdentityId The user id for the user this URL should be generated for
+     *                         (to override it from assuming the currently logged in user)
+     * @param expires The number of seconds before the URL expires

replies.bodyText: i got the name directly from iOS but I'm also not a fan of "expires". I'll leave it as is for platform parity, but we should come up with a better name for it collectively. I was thinking if we could just pass a Date directly with the name expiration because that's how the S3 client takes it anyways.
replies.author: raphkim

timeline.bodyText: Should probably copy over the .expires(...) as well?
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

timeline.message: Fix inaccurate copyright year for newly added classes

timeline.bodyText: Later there is getRequest().weBelieveItsNotNull() so if the superclass constructor doesn’t require non-null, then this constructor should.
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

timeline.bodyText: Should it be called generatePresignedUrl to make clear that the URL doesn’t already exist. Otherwise right now this looks like an accessory method to a cached variable

replies.bodyText: The storage service isn't exposed to the customer anyways so I think it's okay. I gave it the get prefix to be more aligned with getUrl() public API.

+package com.amplifyframework.storage.result;
+
+import androidx.annotation.NonNull;
+
+import com.amplifyframework.core.async.Result;
+
+import java.net.URL;
+import java.util.Objects;
+
+/**
+ * The result of a call to get an item's URL from the Storage category.
+ */
+public final class StorageGetUrlResult implements Result {
+    private final URL url;
+
+    private StorageGetUrlResult(URL url) {
+        this.url = url;
+    }
+
+    /**
+     * Gets the presigned URL.
+     * @return presigned URL
+     */
+    @NonNull
+    public URL getUrl() {
+        return url;
+    }
+
+    /**
+     * Creates a new StorageGetUrlResult containing the presigned URL
+     * of requested object.
+     * @param url The presigned URL
+     * @return A StorageGetUrlResult
+     */
+    @NonNull
+    public static StorageGetUrlResult fromUrl(@NonNull URL url) {
+        return new StorageGetUrlResult(Objects.requireNonNull(url));
